comment.diff_hunk:
@@ -143,11 +143,11 @@ There are also a variety of test programs built under the `tests` directory:
 
 To run one or more ciphers only once use `--mem-bench`, which is suitable for memory usage profiling:
 
-	tests/test_kex --mem-bench ntru
+	tests/test_kex --mem-bench FIXME
comment.body: We shouldn't leave FIXME. In fact, we should remove test_kex altogether.

pull_request.title: Remove kex_ntru from master (issue #370).
pull_request.body:
Redux attempt at removing kex_ntru, starting from master to avoid merge conflicts:
https://github.com/open-quantum-safe/liboqs/issues/370

There are still kex_ntru references in the VisualStudio dir.
@christianpaquin would you mind updating the VisualStudio part on this branch?

Some documentation also needs updates where I've put FIXME placeholders. I'm not sure of what that is to be replaced with.

repo.name: liboqs
repo.description: C library for quantum-resistant cryptographic algorithms.

repo.description: C library for quantum-resistant cryptographic algorithms.

comment.diff_hunk:
@@ -143,11 +143,11 @@ There are also a variety of test programs built under the `tests` directory:
 
 To run one or more ciphers only once use `--mem-bench`, which is suitable for memory usage profiling:
 
-	tests/test_kex --mem-bench ntru
+	tests/test_kex --mem-bench FIXME
 
-You may also get instant memory usage results of an algorithm (e.g. ntru) by running [valgrind's massif tool](http://valgrind.org/docs/manual/ms-manual.html) by running
+You may also get instant memory usage results of an algorithm (e.g. FIXME) by running [valgrind's massif tool](http://valgrind.org/docs/manual/ms-manual.html) by running
comment.body: Use something other than FIXME; perhaps the default KEM alg.
